item.title: Programming: Easy, Peasy
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: It is now summer (for most of us at least!). Have you ever tried to rename hundreds of files, or tried to organise some data files …

item.title: The Mt Gox Bitcoin Debacle
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: The fledgling cryptocurrency Bitcoin suffered one of its biggest setbacks this past week when the (formerly) largest exchange Mt. Gox filed for bankruptcy protection. The beleaguered exchange has been marred by a string of management problems before it filed for bankruptcy protection. Yet, the …

item.title: Tired of all those Wires?
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: I hate wires. Every time I look at the back of my PC and I see the bunch of wires, my OCD kicks in. Luckily, I can usually sit at my desk and pretend the wires are not there. Not for the mobile phone. When you need to charge it, transfer data, or listen to music, you have to pluck some bloody cables …

item.title: Fancy shmancy tech from Santa
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: Every year, as Christmas nears, I would like to think that I have some really rich and wealthy relative who is a Lord somewhere, perhaps some Lord of the Silicon. I would then write up a list of five items I would really like to have and then present it to them, knowing that I would probably get …

item.title: Encryption moving forward
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: The recent spate of NSA tapping data and storing huge amount of internet traffic has been rather worrying. The exposé courtesy of Edward Snowden has made end-users more aware of the need for encryption, and accelerated the process of enhancing the security between end users and the service providers …

item.title: Google Releases the Nexus 5
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: After many weeks of speculations, leaks, and overwhelming anticipation, Google has finally taken the wraps off their new flagship phone, the Nexus 5. The Nexus 5 is, like the Nexus 4, manufactured by LG and modelled after one of their flagship phones, and comes in black and white colours. The Nexus …

item.title: The PokéPositives of X & Y
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: Pokémon X & Y saw the first ever simultaneous release of a Nintendo title worldwide. item.title: Y wouldn’t you buy these amazing games? Its Pokémon, just X 2!
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: In the 17 years since the first Pokémon games were released, Game Freak have been churning out generations of iterative games, each improving upon their predecessors gradually. Now in its sixth generation of the games, Pokémon X & Y delivers another more-of-the-same but greatly improved game …

item.title: Back to School, Technically

item.description: It’s the time of the year again. After a very beautiful summer, it’s time to get ready to face the cold, harsh winter and get ready for a new academic year. item.title: Updating Android without updating!

item.description: Google I/O has traditionally, for the past few years at least, been an event where Google unveils the newest and shiniest version of Android to the world. item.title: Charging your Phone... Wirelessly
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: Qi. This sounds like some sort of Chinese “life energy” philosophy, but that’s not what we are talking about here. Pronounced “chee”, Qi is a wireless inductive power standard that is increasingly being adopted by handset manufacturers such as Nokia and LG for inclusion into their handsets. For …

item.title: Love for Android Fragmentation
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: The big F word in the Android world: fragmentation. This is the word that Android sceptics and users both decry and hate. It is both the bane and boon of Android. When Google made Android open source, it created a whole new set of problems and opportunities for users. Android handset makers have …

item.title: Google Nexus 4, worth it?
item.author: Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: The best effort at a Nexus phone so far, albeit with some teething issues. When Google announced the Nexus One phone in 2010, it was not too much of a success. item.title: Reddit: Freedom of speech?

item.title: Will W8 cause us grief?
item.author: Jason Parmar,Yong Wen Chua,
item.description: Some of us are not normal people (but then again, we are Imperial students).
